output.name: Emory University Theoretical Biophysics
output.organizationTypeJustification: Emory University Theoretical Biophysics is based at Emory University, hosts academic-style repositories focusing on computational and theoretical research, and is led by a university faculty member, indicating an academic research group.
output.description: The Emory University Theoretical Biophysics group, led by Prof. Ilya Nemenman, develops computational, statistical, and theoretical methods for understanding biological systems. Research topics include information theory, inference algorithms, neural decoding, population dynamics, and quantitative models of cellular and organismal processes.
disciplineJustification: The group focuses on theoretical modeling and physical principles in biological contexts, aligning with Physics.
The research addresses biological systems such as bacterial populations and C. elegans, indicating Biology.
The development of statistical inference and information estimation methods reflects a core reliance on Statistics.
Algorithmic learning, non-Gaussian learning, and inference methods align with Theoretical computer science.
Modeling of complex biological networks and system dynamics corresponds to Systems science and engineering.
